channel.title: xylem | Gordon Beeming
channel.description: Gordon Beeming - Father • Husband • Triathlete • SSW Solution Architect

item.title: Keep Your Domain Clean: Deserializing with Private Setters in C#
item.description: Ever created a perfectly encapsulated C# domain object with private setters, only to find System.Text.Json can't deserialize data back into it? You don't have to expose your setters! Let's explore a clean solution.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: The Deceptive Simplicity of Polymorphism in .NET APIs
item.description: You add one more state to your polymorphic API response, and suddenly everything breaks. This is the story of a subtle bug, a frustrating debugging session, and the one line of code that fixed it all.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Slaying the EF Core Cartesian Explosion with AsSplitQuery()
item.description: You built a rich domain model with aggregates and child collections, but now your queries are painfully slow. Learn how a one-line change in Entity Framework Core, .AsSplitQuery(), can fix the dreaded "Cartesian Explosion" and make your app fly.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: EF Core's Hidden Identity Crisis: The Owned Entity Cloning Problem
item.description: Your integration tests all pass, but your live app throws a cryptic EF Core error about modifying a key that doesn't even exist. Let's dive into the fascinating reason why and how to fix it.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Taking up the last slot... if you know you know 😘
item.description: Ever felt like you just *had* to squeeze in and make your presence known? Sometimes, a well-timed appearance is all it takes to complete the picture. This one's for those who appreciate the subtle art of fitting in… right at the very end.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: From Conversation to Documentation: A Modern Dev Workflow with AI
item.description: We solve complex problems and then face the daunting task of writing documentation. What if the documentation wrote itself? Discover a workflow that turns a simple conversation with an AI into polished ADRs and blog posts, saving you hours.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Solving the Parallels Networking Puzzle: Accessing Mac localhost from a Windows VM
item.description: Ever tried to access a web app running on your Mac from a Windows VM in Parallels and been met with connection errors? You are not alone. Follow this troubleshooting guide to solve the mystery of network binding, firewalls, and the real culprit hiding in your hosts file.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: The Mysterious Case of the Failing Azure SQL Deployment
item.description: A perfectly stable GitHub Actions deployment to Azure SQL suddenly fails with a misleading 'Identity not found' error. Follow the debugging journey to uncover the real culprit that has nothing to do with the identity.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Goodbye Microsoft Teams bar... Hello Productivity
item.description: We've all been there, you're in a meeting, you start sharing your screen and things are going great... next up you need to do something at the top of your screen and you can't because the Microsoft Teams bar is in the way. You can't move it, you can't hide it, you can't do anything about it. Or can you?
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Improving your git efficiency using git alias
item.description: Have you ever felt like typing out git commands requires too much effort, yet you don't want to switch to a GUI because that brings it's own set of problems? Have you tried using git aliases to make your workflow more efficient? Over the last couple of weeks I've shown many people how I'm using git alias to improve my workflows, if you're interested in improving your workflow, watch this video 💪😅
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Deploying .NET templates using GitHub Actions
item.description: Once you've created a .NET template, you should automate the updates of the package using GitHub actions to remove the effort required in publishing updates
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Visual Studio Item Templates vs .NET Templates in 2023
item.description: Long ago, one of the ways we'd get some reuse out of standard and utility files would be by exporting item templates. Since the .NET CLI rolled around, the approach has been different and much easier.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Is this thing on?
item.description: Sometimes you just need an accountability partner... or 2, and then you'll start course-correcting
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Blazor Server events not triggering when hosted behind Cloudflare
item.description: Are you hosting your Blazor Server app behind Cloudflare? Are you having issues with events not triggering? Check your configuration 😉.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Playing with Azure and Terraform
item.description: I recently presented "Playing with Azure and Terraform" at our user group locally in Durban, there were some requests for a recording so I thought I'd share it here 😊 We play with a lot of different tech in this session like GitHub Codespaces, Azure, Cloudflare and Snyk
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Scanning Infrastructure as Code (IaC) for vulnerabilities
item.description: In the modern world where it feels like every sentence has a Dev⭐Ops word in it, 1 that is probably used more than most is DevSecOps.When teams focus on DevSecOps they make sure to integrate security into every phase of development, this includes scanning for vulnerabilities as soon as possible. This videos shows you briefly how you can use Snyk to scan your terraform templates for vulnerabilities from your CLI as well as part of every commit pushed to GitHub.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Interacting with Cloudflare DNS and Origin Certs using Terraform
item.description: In this video we'll take a look at connecting to Cloudflare with terraform to fully automate a full (strict) SSL/TLS encryption mode setup We'll also cover setting up a basic nginx server which we'll use to validate that our setup is working as expected.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Managing GitHub secrets using terraform
item.description: In this video we'll take a look at Managing GitHub secrets using terraform as well as federated identities from GitHub into Azure. You should only be storing secrets if you absolutely need to, in this demo although we are only accessing storage accounts the change from a storage connection string to Azure Federated Identity means that we can access any of resource the identity has access too using RBAC which is a much better overall approach.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Building basic Azure infrastructure using Terraform
item.description: In this video we'll take a look at how to build some basic Azure infrastructure using Terraform.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: GitHub Projects and Issues
item.description: Are you tired of your average planning tools? Take a look at what you could be using if you switched to GitHub Projects and Issues 😉
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Setting up commit signature verification for GitHub
item.description: Ever wondered why some commits show verified and others don't? Take a look at how you can make sure all your commits are verified. Commands from this video are available in this gist https://gist.github.com/DevStarOps/6c88482ecd632ba04d68d9e15590b4a2
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Moving Repos to GitHub from Azure DevOps - GitHub Quick Tips
item.description: This is a Quick GitHub Tip on Moving Repos to GitHub from Azure DevOps
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Profile README - GitHub Quick Tips
item.description: This is a Quick GitHub Tip on Profile Readmes
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Allow project users to manage Permissions Groups in Azure DevOps
item.description: In this video I'm going to show you... How to allow project users to manage Permissions Groups in Azure DevOps that aren't project administrators
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Developing software for the modern world using only your browser and GitHub
item.description: In this video I'm going to show you... How to develop software for the modern world using only your browser and GitHub.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Having fun with GitHub Codespaces, docker, swagger codegen cli
item.description: In this video I'm going to show you... How you can use GitHub Codespaces to prototype an idea and put it into action... or should I say actions with nothing more than your browser.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.description: In this video I'm going to talk to you about... Rethinking your application boundary and using Cloudflare

item.description: In this video I'm going to show you... Migrating pipelines and releases in Azure DevOps

item.title: Migrating Test artifacts and all other work item types using the Azure DevOps
item.description: In this video I'm going to show you... Migrating Test artifacts (and all other work item types) using the Azure DevOps Migration Tools
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: How to migrate SVN and TFVC repositories to git repositories in Azure DevOps
item.description: In this video I'm going to show you... How to migrate SVN and TFVC repositories to git repositories in Azure DevOps

item.title: How to migrate git repositories to Azure DevOps
item.description: In this video I'm going to show you... How to migrate git repositories to Azure DevOps

item.title: How to move Work Items between projects in Azure DevOps
item.description: In this video I'm going to show you... How to move Work Items between projects in Azure DevOps

item.title: How to delete a team project in Azure DevOps
item.description: In this video I'm going to show you... How to delete a team project in Azure DevOps

item.title: How to recovery a deleted team project in Azure DevOps
item.description: In this video I'm going to show you... How to delete a team project in Azure DevOps

item.title: How to create a team project in Azure DevOps
item.description: In this video I'm going to show you... How to create a team project in Azure DevOps

item.title: How to use the same editor as Visual Studio Code in your sites
item.description: Wondering how you can use the same editor as Visual Studio Code in your sites? In this video I'll show you how you can 😀. 0:00 - Introduction 0:25 - Setup basic HTML file 1:55 - Add monaco editor html tags 3:23 - Use monaco colorizeElement functionality 5:17 - Create a monaco editor 9:46 - Monaco editor "Cannot read property 'AddEventListener' of null 10:38 - Use npm to install monaco editor dependencies 12:19 - Exploring the monaco editor playground 13:52 - Thank you for watching
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: [ code snippet ] JsonPropertyConverter.cs
item.description: JsonConverter that works with System.Text.Json allows having a string property that will just store the json element string instead of trying to parse the properties into a complex object
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: 2020 Journey to 120
item.description: This post is just to kick off and mention that I will be doing a series of videos out on YouTube about my 2020 Journey to 120.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: How to lower the real cost of a SQL Server Virtual Machine in Azure
item.description: Whenever you take out an Azure VM you generally get a single disk which is not that big, when you select a SQL Server based VM (even web edition) you automatically get a 1TB disk, if you are using managed disks you pay for that whole TB even if you are only using 1GB of it. This post will show you how you can lower the price of that virtual machine if you are in this situation
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Raising awareness and reliable information sources for #COVID19 by adding a banner to your websites
item.description: Recently talking to people it's obvious that a lot of people are either not following what is going on globally and in lots of cases have information that seems to have been obtained from unreliable sources MyBroadband released a post titled "New rules for all co.za websites and ISPs during coronavirus outbreak" which mentioned that ISPs needed a visible link to one of the South African information sites for corona virus so thought it would be a useful thing for more people to add banners in general to their sites linking to a trusted source for corona virus information
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Create pfx certificate file for Azure Web Apps from Cloudflare origin cert using openssl
item.description: Every time I create a new project using Azure Web Apps or even IIS and I need to add a pfx file for end to end https, Cloudflare gives you a private key and certificate but you can't use those directly with Azure Web Apps and I keep forgetting how to do this exactly so as I do sometimes I'm going to post the steps so that it's helpful to others as well as future me.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Publish aspnet core sites to Azure easily using GitHub actions
item.description: Have a site sitting in GitHub that you currently maybe manually deploy to Azure or use some other tool? Why not useGitHub Actionsto quickly and easily publish to Azure. I was pushing a small site (Guid.Empty) to Azure through GitHub and decided to document the couple steps for future me 😋... oh and for you of course 😅
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: The importance of regression testing and real world security consequences
item.description: Organizations often put a lot of effort around testing their products, they'll put tons of effort in unit testing, integration testing across their UI and API layers but sometimes have a strategy of covering everything. This doesn't always add value to their pipelines because the metric that is being chased is not value which agreeably is a hard thing to measure but rather it's a coverage metric. To start with I don't know if testing strategy is what was happening for TicTocTrack but is something that is definitely highlighted as something that would have been valuable for them. A security vulnerability discovered around a year ago from a fellow MVP and security expert Troy Hunt was patched and then earlier this year I re-discovered it
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Find organizations linked to your AAD tenant in Azure DevOps
item.description: Did you know that you can get a list of all organizations linked to your Azure Active Directory tenant? Since august this has been possible 😁
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: GitHub actions… CI in 5 clicks
item.description: If you don't know yet what GitHub actions are you can read about it on the GitHub Actions feature on GitHub. In short on the 8th of August GitHub announced an update to their actions which you can read about in this blog post. it's a very easy way to automate anything from any event in GitHub.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Missing ctrl + enter in Visual Studio to commit changes? Here's how you can add it
item.description: So something that you've probably noticed when using dev tools in the web and Visual Studio Code is that you can hit ctrl + enter and with this you may have noticed that in Visual Studio you can't do that. Below you'll see how you can add this to your IDE.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Adding routes to Strava and then to Garmin devices
item.description: I've spoken to a couple of people who want to add routes to their Garmin devices but the path isn't as straight forward as you'd imagine it should/can be.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Creating an Azure dashboard for Application Insights in 1,2,3
item.description: So watching this weeks asp.net community standup ASP.NET Community Standup - December 11, 2018 - 2.2 Release Party! and Scott Hanselman shows how to make a dashboard for your application insights resource in no time.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: #TYMHKON: How do I follow what's happening with Azure DevOps?
item.description: #TYMHKON: What is it?
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: How to Tweet Azure Pipeline activity easily
item.description: A while back I created a service linked to Twitter that tweets when your pipeline has completed in Azure Pipelines. This post is going to show you how you can easily tweet when your builds complete .
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: #TYMHKON: Public projects in Azure DevOps
item.description: #TYMHKON: What is it?
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: #TYMHKON: What is it?
item.description: TYMHKON is something random that to me looks like it could be Japanese? Not sure what makes me think that when seeing it but what it really stands for is Things You May Have Known Or Not!
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Building libraries that target multiple frameworks
item.description: I've generally built libraries wrong by placing all binaries in the root and it's worked ok for now so why change it. I might also add that these libraries have been for internal use so no real reason for not doing this I guess.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Turning on the new navigation for Visual Studio Team Services
item.description: Although I'm hoping everyone reading this doesn't need this I thought I'd share anyway. A little under a month ago Jeremy Epling (@jeremy_epling) posted on the Microsoft DevOps Blog about the New Navigation for Visual Studio Team Services. I'm not going to repeat the very detailed blog post but I am going to show you how to enabled the amazing experience quickly.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: A journey worth taking
item.description: The post is going to go over the last 10 years (7 in more detail) and how I applied a little self control (eventually) and have sort of changed how I motivate myself to try better and why I came to do that. You can almost think of the journey as being a good movie where the dude in high school has everything, somehow loses it (well finding other great things) and then finds his way again (sort of).
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: How do I fix HTTP Error 502.5 - Process Failure when hosting in IIS with dotnet core
item.description: I received a new error today that I haven't received before when deploying dotnet core apps. It was as the title suggest a "HTTP Error 502.5 - Process Failure" error
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Set which chrome profile for Visual Studio to use
item.description: At MVP Summit this year one of the valuable things I learnt (which I can share ) was from Colin Dembovsky (ALM MVP) which was Using Chrome to Solve Identity Hell. Now I knew chrome profiles existed but never thought of using them to solve the problem of different identities, in-private mode was a way of doing things but you always lost that when closing the session so wasn't that great. Not going to talk much about that here, you can read his post to find out more.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Creating a new branch in @VSTS
item.description: This is a quick reference post that shows you how to create a branch in VSTS and TFS.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Setting wild card branch policies in @VSTS
item.description: I've probably mentioned it before but keeping up with what's happening with VSTS is incredible hard with their 3 week cadence and generally huge set of features each 3 weeks. This week at MVP Summit I had what I thought would be a cool request to allow wild card branch policies. I was thinking of writing a console app to do this but thought it would be interesting to ask the product group as it's part of the many benefits of being a MVP .
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Setting up 2 factor authentication and email verification with .net core 2.0
item.description: Today I played with a new .net core template just to see what the authentication options were out the box and was surprised to see just how easy it is to go from nothing to having a base project that has authentication fully baked in with 2 factor authentication and email verification.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Creating an asynchronous AuthorizeAttribute in MVC
item.description: A couple days ago I needed to call a remote web api call in my AuthorizeAttribute sometimes but as mentioned in this (Is it possible to use async/await in MVC 4 AuthorizeAttribute?) StackOverflow question (and other forums) it isn't supported but is in the newer .net core. Unfortunately the project I needed this on was traditional MVC so I was left still finding a way .
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Moving Application Insights resources between subscriptions in Azure
item.description: There is documentation available for Move resources to new resource group or subscription but things are easier to do with exact sample code so here it goes . The steps below will work for moving between Resource Groups as well, you'll just skip some steps that would be obvious.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: BenchmarkDotNet: IsBoolean method
item.description: This post might seem weird and is slightly. It's really just a pointer as with all my posts to send people to instead of sharing lots of text "on the down low" 😁.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Work Around for .NET Framework 4.7 or a later update is already installed on this computer
item.description: I see this message most times I format my machines after opening existing projects in Visual Studio and I always forgot how I solve it
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Connecting agents to TFS using integrated security on http from external domain
item.description: If you have TFS on the domain but you are trying to connect agents to it from outside the domain and TFS is not running on https then this post is for you.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Searching in VSTS/TFS
item.description: This post is largely showing off a cool feature of chrome but the core focus is how you can be more productive with VSTS search
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Bulk import git repositories into VSTS/TFS
item.description: With the rate that the VSTS team releases with all the features they releasing it's hard to know everything that exists in VSTS. I recently needed to migrate git repos from various Team Project Collections (TPC) into a single Team Project and started out doing it very manually and slowly progresses to importing over 100 in a couple hours .
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Battling to Join Insider Preview?
item.description: Today I tried to join one of my machines to the insider preview. Most people if they get issues would probably take it as a sign that putting the broken bits on their machine was a bad idea and the universe has saved them…I need my broken bits fix .
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Converting Html to Pdf using C# and magic!
item.description: Everyone at some point needs to convert and html page into a PDF for some reason or another. For this I've always used a component which was cheap at the time (and is far from it now). This component has worked well for the last 8(ish) years, most ish in the last while because it doesn't deal well with https sites. When contacting the vendor they said hey but our latest version which can be expected I guess because it's 8 years down the line but then came the it's ALL OF THE $ . The last issue is that the component I used doesn't work in Azure. That lead me to some investigation and then ultimately this post.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Using ngrok to test web apps on mobile while developing
item.description: I often never really test on mobile properly because most sites are responsive so it's easier to just resize your browser and test like that. This works great until you trying to get the perfect mobile experience and looking at every element like how drop lists present themselves with different content taking into account how wrapping might happen in mobile browser controls (which is different from web browser, even in chrome ). A long time ago I briefly used ngrok just to test how it works and now I use it constantly for testing apps while they are still in development.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Generating code documentation using Ghost Doc Enterprise
item.description: I've recently started catching up with all the blogs that I've wanted to write and have had flagged to write for a long time. This one I have had flagged since 26 January 2016.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Setting up a standard continuous integration build with VSTS/TFS
item.description: If you do a quick Google for pros of setting up continuous integration you'll come across a lot of articles about how good setting up continuous integration (CI) is compared to googling cons of setting up continuous integration which basically gives you the same posts of the the pros search so we won't dig too much into that now .
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Setting up .net core continuous integration build with VSTS/TFS
item.description: You might be wondering after recently posting Setting up a standard continuous integration build with VSTS/TFS why I'd need to post specifically on .net core. After all it's still a Visual Studio solution so things should just work, the keyword here is should . Things didn't just work when I tried to get this working so decided to share my experience here (as well as document it for myself later ).
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Implementing a dynamic robots.txt
item.description: Firstly you might want to know why would you want to implement a dynamic robots.txt? Isn't it better to just put a static file in the web app? Yes it is but when you running your application on certain platforms like web apps in Azure when you using deployment slots. I found this handy link which explains deployment slots quite nicely , but basically what happens is when you switch 2 slots Azure will do a virtual IP switch so traffic from your slots will now be switched (not the files from each slot).
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: So I installed VS Enterprise 2017 and have no MTM, where is it?
item.description: If you've installed Visual Studio 2017 Enterprise and weren't one of the people that went over to the Individual Components tab to see what you weren't installing you probably don't have Microsoft Test Manager installed.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Using C# 6 to make 'bad' SQL awesome
item.description: I'm busy going through Pluralsight watching Exploring C# 6 with Jon Skeet by Rob Conery. Jon Skeet goes ahead and makes this epic method that looks like it's so naughty but is pretty cool.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Easily adding auditing to a Entity Framework Code First project
item.description: If you've done any amount of development where you need to interact with data you'd know that at some point customers or stakeholders always want to know who made that change or when was that change made. To answer these questions you'd look to your auditing which in most cases is the last thing people think about adding into their apps for some reason.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Opening apps from the directory you in as Administrator
item.description: The other day I saw a post that Greg Duncan shared about opening CMD and PowerShell from the directory you in.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: SSMS 2016 where have my line breaks gone?
item.description: I'm hoping it's not just me but one of the things I was missing from SSMS 2014 is that I had my line breaks when copying large text fields out of the query results. For a long time I have been putting it off and only using SSMS 2014, last week I re-installed my Operating System and decided not to install SSMS 2014 just for this 1 feature.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Visual Studio Team Services Overview - Video Series
item.description: A couple weeks ago I was asked to present at DUT to a group of students. The presentation was quite a long one so I had to cut some bits out in order to present in the timeslot that I had. So I decided that I'd record all the content and post it up so that others can potentially benefit from it as well.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Making a Cake Day
item.description: Today I decided to record a presentation I did recently. It will be posted soon but in the meantime here's something else. While I was busy recording my wife (Tiani) decided that her and the kids would make a cake. It was as usual one of the best cakes I've tasted. If you haven't seen any of her other creations take a look at her Facebook page3 Tiers Novalty Cakes, below is my cake for my 25th birthday cake.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: VSTS widget for GitHub badges
item.description: When I first heard about the SDK for widgets in Visual Studio Team Services (VSTS) I wanted to make a couple of widgets, one of these was a GitHub widget that would show some info from any GitHub repo on your VSTS dashboard. This can can be helpful when you have your source open on GitHub but still work out of VSTS.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Setting up TFS Build Agents fast
item.description: So you could make a script that can do the bits below but if you don't here is how you can easily create build agents fast for TFS 2015+ or VSO.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Load testing using Azure
item.description: So everyone wants to have the ultimate system that never breaks can handle 'all' the users and shows no strain when doing so. How do you accomplish something like this? Well you could hire developers that know all the best ways to do everything, experts in everything related to configuring applications to run the best that they can on the hardware and software it sits on but what's the odds of that happening. The other option is to have a bank account that is never ending and throw 'all' the hardware at your application to make sure it doesn't ever have a slow day but then how are you making your money, how do you know when 'all' the hardware isn't enough.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Browsing localhost with the Microsoft Edge Browser

item.title: A 'Hello World' for VSTS Extensions
item.description: So if you haven't heard yet VSO Extensions are now in a private preview where you can sign up to get into the preview on extensions integration site. These extensions in the shortest sentence a supported way of doing customizations to VSO that will replace any of the "hacky" extensions that you may be playing around with at the moment like Tiago Pascal's Task Board Enhancer or maybe you have even created your own following similar steps to what I show in my TFS 2013 Customization book.

item.title: They said Select * was bad but...
item.description: So speaking to any smart database people they will generally tell you that the SELECT * FROM ... is a bad idea and should not be used. Today (well would of been if I didn't procrastinate) I spent many hours debugging something from the wrong places because I used SELECT *. Below is what I found out =). Rennie Moodley helped me understand what was happening after I figured out where the problem was, helped me create the sample code below and then the 2 of us and Christopher Swart poked at and improve the sample and found some more weirdness which you'll also see below.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Fixing The process cannot access the file because it is being used by another process. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x80070020)
item.description: I had some "Weird" things happening with IIS on one of my developer machines. After trouble shooting for a while I decided that was definitely not winning and removed all features from my pc that were even the slightest related to IIS, my pc required a restart so I did. When it came back I re-enabled all the features as I would normally do and then attempted to put my dev site in IIS. For some reason all the sites were stopped and when trying to start them I received the message

item.title: Creating a new Azure Active Directory User
item.description: Open the Azure Management Portal, login and then navigate to the Active Directory tab and click on the Active Directory resource you want to add a user to, alternatively create a new Azure Active Directory resource and then come back to this post.

item.title: Using Azure Resource Manager
item.description: In the new Azure Portal you create all your resources in Resource Groups, there is also as part of the Azure SDK's a module called AzureResourceManager by default the module loaded for the Azure SDK is AzureServiceManagement. A blurb from one of the Azure documentation page reads
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Application Insights for Windows Store Apps in Azure Portal
item.description: If you've been using Application Insights for a while now you would have noticed that with recent Visual Updates the Application Insights SDK had been updated to use a new version that logs AI data into the new Azure Portal. From this if you use Windows Store Apps you would probably have noticed that if you instrument a Windows Store application with the new SDK that you can't actually find your data anywhere although you can see it being logged from the Visual Studio Output window and using Fiddler. The good news is that you will soon be able to have a great experience with the new AI SDK for Windows Store apps as you do for your currently for your web applications, the better news is that below you'll see how to use the new SDK for your Store Apps and see the data in the Azure Portal.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

We're running it in conjunction with LinkedIn group LIDNUG (LinkedIn .NET User Group) who have over 52,000 members so we're hoping to get a big list of people signed up! Feel free to sign up yourself or let anyone know who you think might be interested in registering.

When I first started doing customizations I used the TFS Power Tools to upload changes which is a lot of effort because you are uploading one work item definition at a time into one team project.

Although this wasn't exactly what I was looking for right now I gave it a try and then thought to share it after I made a couple of changes to make it work on my machine and categorize a bit more . You can grab the script off GitHub Gist organise-music.ps1.

item.title: How to Enforce Check-In Policies
item.description: So one of the benefits of using Server side Plugins is that you can't override them. The problem with this is that the users don't know that the policy is in place until they check-in their code. Wouldn't it be nice if me as a user were told this is what I need to do as in see the requirements from check-in policies but then to make the administrators or business rules that require the policies to also be happy.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Start-BitsTransfer : Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
item.description: Today I find myself with yet another bit of functionality that only works when you are running in Administrator Mode. A while back I had Full Admin Mode always enabled, downside of this is the store apps don't work at all. Up side is your PC works as expected . I created a PowerShell script to download Channel 9 videos as described in my post Easily download Ch9 videos, this script worked perfectly but recently started breaking with the error
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)

item.title: Add work item links from check in comments
item.description: The other night while watching the Visual Studio 2013 Launch a question came up asking if the team had added support yet for automatically linking work items to the change set created when checking in as it currently is in Git. Currently this functionality doesn't exist for TFVC Check ins, at the time I didn't think anything of it but tonight for some reason I thought "hey that would be something simply to create and should hopefully make lives easier for developers". So I opened up Visual Studio and at the same time started a new project on GitHub for TFS Server Plugins. The code required for the plugin was very basic, basically just checked the comment from the check in with a regular expression and then added the links between the change set and all the IDs found in the comments.
item.author: website@gordonbeeming.com (Gordon Beeming)
